bestBHT.bht: In this parable, the people of Israel are represented by the vineyard, and the spiritual guides are symbolized by the husbandmen. God sends His messengers to cultivate righteousness, but they are shamefully mistreated and sent away empty-handed. This parable reminds us of the responsibility of spiritual leaders to nurture righteousness among the people and warns of the consequences of disregarding God's messengers. The rejection of these messengers reflects a disregard for God's authority and His desire for righteousness.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: vineyard—(See on :-). In Matthew 21:33 additional points are given, taken literally from Matthew 21:33- :, to fix down the application and sustain it by Old Testament authority.
husbandmen—the ordinary spiritual guides of the people, under whose care and culture the fruits of righteousness might be yielded.
went, &c.—leaving it to the laws of the spiritual husbandry during the whole length of the Jewish economy.
Marvin Vincent: He sent yet [προσεθετο πεμψαι] . Lit., he added to send. A Hebrew form of expression.
Archibald T. Robertson: He sent yet another (προσεθετο ετερον πεμψα). Literally,
he added to send another . A clear Hebraism repeated in verse Luke 20:12 and also in Luke 19:11.
John Gill: And entreated him shamefully; putting him to open shame, using him in a very ignominious and shameful manner.
Which it was a shame to relate, and which was shameful for them to do.
And sent him away empty; as they had done the other.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Luke 20:11, the parable of the vineyard is told, with the vineyard symbolizing the people of Israel and the husbandmen representing the spiritual guides. The sending of the servant to collect fruit reflects the efforts of God to bring forth righteousness among the people. However, the servants are treated shamefully and sent away empty-handed, emphasizing the nation's rejection of God's messengers. This parable serves as a reminder of the responsibility of spiritual leaders to cultivate righteousness among the people and the consequences of ignoring this duty.

In this parable, the vineyard represents the people of Israel and the husbandmen symbolize the spiritual guides entrusted with cultivating righteousness. Despite God's efforts to bring forth fruit through His messengers, they are treated shamefully and sent away empty-handed. This serves as a reminder of the responsibility that spiritual leaders have to nurture righteousness among the people. The parable highlights the consequences of neglecting this duty and emphasizes the rejection of God's messengers by the nation.

The parable of the vineyard in Luke 20:11 reflects the relationship between the people of Israel represented by the vineyard and the spiritual guides characterized as the husbandmen. God sends His messengers to bring forth righteousness, but they are shamefully mistreated and sent away empty-handed. This parable serves as a reminder of the responsibility of spiritual leaders to cultivate righteousness among the people and demonstrates the consequences of rejecting God's messengers. The rejection of these messengers by the nation is a reflection of their disregard for God's authority and His desire for righteousness.

In this parable, the people of Israel are represented by the vineyard, and the spiritual guides are symbolized by the husbandmen. God sends His messengers to cultivate righteousness, but they are shamefully mistreated and sent away empty-handed. This parable reminds us of the responsibility of spiritual leaders to nurture righteousness among the people and warns of the consequences of disregarding God's messengers. The rejection of these messengers reflects a disregard for God's authority and His desire for righteousness.

The parable of the vineyard in Luke 20:11 portrays the people of Israel as the vineyard and the spiritual leaders as the husbandmen. God sends His messengers to cultivate righteousness, but they face mistreatment and are sent away empty-handed. This parable serves as a reminder of the responsibility of spiritual guides to nurture righteousness among the people and warns of the consequences of rejecting God's messengers. It reflects a disregard for God's authority and His desire for righteousness when His messengers are rejected by the nation.
